entry.title: üß† Por que SABER n√£o √© suficiente: o papel da intelig√™ncia emocional no seu sucesso profissional
entry.content:
üß© Este conte√∫do √© diferente do que voc√™ costuma ver aqui no meu perfil, mas √© essencial para qualquer profissional.

Hoje n√£o vou falar de SAP ou Integra√ß√£o no SAP CPI. Vou falar sobre algo que impacta diretamente sua carreira: a forma como voc√™ se comporta, se comunica, lida com pessoas e reage a situa√ß√µes.

Tudo isso est√° ligado √† sua intelig√™ncia emocional. E ela pode ser o fator decisivo entre crescer ou estagnar na sua trajet√≥ria profissional.

Neste artigo, quero compartilhar com voc√™ uma reflex√£o sobre QI x QE, como isso afeta seu dia a dia no trabalho e na fam√≠lia, e como a ferramenta DISC pode te ajudar a evoluir como profissional.

üíºN√£o h√° d√∫vida de que, para termos sucesso na vida profissional, precisamos desenvolver habilidades. E normalmente, o foco est√° nas habilidades cognitivas, como fazer uma faculdade, aprender ingl√™s, fazer cursos‚Ä¶ tudo isso relacionado ao nosso QI (Coeficiente de Intelig√™ncia).

E sim, isso √© importante!

Mas‚Ä¶ ü§î E se eu te disser que essas habilidades representam apenas 20% do que voc√™ precisa para conquistar o sucesso?

üìöO que realmente faz a diferen√ßa: o QE

Segundo Daniel Goleman, PhD em Psicologia e autor do livro "Intelig√™ncia Emocional", 80% do sucesso est√° diretamente relacionado ao QE (Coeficiente de Intelig√™ncia Emocional).

Ou seja, o que mais te impede de alcan√ßar o sucesso n√£o √© o que voc√™ SABE, mas o que voc√™ FAZ (ou deixa de FAZER).

üß© Diferen√ßa entre QI e QE

Vamos organizar isso de forma simples e clara. Veja essa tabela comparativa:

Resumo Comparativo  entre QI e QE

Resumo

Cada habilidade √© desenvolvida e utilizada de forma diferente.

O QI representa o nosso SABER, enquanto o QE est√° ligado ao FAZER.

O QI se desenvolve com o tempo: engatinhar, sentar, andar, falar‚Ä¶ J√° o QE nasce de est√≠mulos, experi√™ncias e observa√ß√µes. Ele est√° profundamente conectado ao sentimento: o que importa n√£o √© o que aconteceu, mas como voc√™ se SENTIU diante da experi√™ncia.

Ah, ent√£o Neylon, voc√™ est√° dizendo que eu posso abandonar as habilidades cognitivas?

‚Äî Claro que n√£o! Se voc√™ fizer isso, n√£o vai alcan√ßar sucesso.

‚ö°Saber n√£o √© suficiente

Vamos sair um pouco do ambiente profissional para entender melhor:

  • üö¨Fumar faz mal? Todo mundo SABE que sim. Mesmo assim, muitos continuam. Por qu√™? Porque n√£o √© o QI que impede, √© o QE. Existe um v√≠cio, sim, mas tamb√©m h√° uma carga emocional que dificulta a mudan√ßa.
  • üèÉ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è Fazer exerc√≠cios faz bem? Tamb√©m todo mundo SABE. Mas nem todo mundo FAZ. O problema n√£o √© o cognitivo, √© o emocional.

üëâOu seja, muitas vezes o problema n√£o √© SABER o que FAZER, √© conseguir FAZER o que SABE.

üëâIsso mostra que, na vida, muitas vezes voc√™ SABE o que precisa fazer, mas n√£o faz. Isso deixa claro que seu lado cognitivo, dado por Deus, funciona perfeitamente, mas suas habilidades emocionais ainda n√£o foram desenvolvidas.

üíºE no trabalho?

Voc√™ SABE que n√£o deve gritar com colegas, ser r√≠spido, ignorar opini√µes... Mas mesmo sabendo, √†s vezes voc√™ FAZ.

Isso √© falta de QI? N√£o. √â sua intelig√™ncia emocional que precisa ser desenvolvida.

üßì "Ah Neylon, mas muito disso √© falta de MATURIDADE, com o tempo a pessoa aprende!"

‚Äî N√£o, maturidade n√£o vem com o tempo.

Se fosse assim, n√£o ver√≠amos pessoas mais velhas cometendo os mesmos erros repetidamente. A maturidade √© uma habilidade emocional, n√£o apenas cognitiva. Isso explica por que existem pessoas mais velhas sem maturidade.

üòîPor que tanta gente est√° frustrada no trabalho?

  • Uma pessoa gosta de explicar tudo com detalhes. Seu colega, mais direto, acha isso desnecess√°rio. Resultado? Frustra√ß√£o.
  • Um chefe √© objetivo e direto. O colaborador sente isso como falta de empatia. Resultado? Mais frustra√ß√£o.
  • Jo√£o teve um dia ruim e respondeu Pedro de forma r√≠spida. Pedro ficou chateado, mas Jo√£o nem percebeu (ou percebeu e ignorou). O que importa aqui n√£o foi a fala em si, mas como PEDRO se SENTIU.

üéØO que √© comum e normal para voc√™ pode ser interpretado de forma totalmente diferente por outra pessoa.E isso acontece no trabalho, em casa, na vida.

üîçE como melhorar isso?

O primeiro passo √© o autoconhecimento.

A ferramenta DISC ajuda voc√™ a entender seu perfil comportamental ‚Äî como voc√™ age, reage, se comunica, e tamb√©m como se relaciona com quem √© diferente de voc√™.

Perfil Neylon Silva

 

üìäOs 4 perfis do DISC (resumido)

  • Dominante: Autoconfiante, direto, orientado a resultados
  • Influente: Comunicativo, entusiasmado, envolvente
  • Est√°vel: Calmo, paciente, cooperativo
  • Anal√≠tico: Cauteloso, preciso, gosta de detalhes

ü§ùQuer saber mais?

üíºVoc√™ pode ser excelente tecnicamente, mas se n√£o souber lidar com pessoas, press√µes e frustra√ß√µes, vai acabar travando seu pr√≥prio crescimento.

Espero que esse conte√∫do tenha te feito refletir. Se quiser conversar mais sobre intelig√™ncia emocional ou aplicar a an√°lise DISC na sua equipe, estou √† disposi√ß√£o.

Afinal, tecnologia leva voc√™ longe, mas comportamento leva voc√™ al√©m. üöÄ

entry.title: Understanding the Belgium B2B e-Invoicing Mandate and the Plant Abroad Scenario
entry.content:
Introduction

From January 1, 2026, structured B2B e-invoicing will become mandatory in Belgium for transactions between businesses established in Belgium.
The requirement applies to all domestic B2B supplies of goods and services where both supplier and buyer are VAT-registered and established in Belgium.

SAP supports the Belgian B2B e-Invoicing mandate through SAP Document and Reporting Compliance (SAP DRC), which enables businesses to create and transmit Peppol BIS Billing 3.0 XML invoices in full compliance via the Peppol network.

For foundational details, refer to Peppol Participant Registration for Belgian Companies 

 

The ‚ÄúPlant Abroad‚Äù Challenge

Businesses operate through foreign legal entities that maintain fixed establishments in Belgium, often configured in SAP using the Plant Abroad functionality.

Scenario:

  • The head company code is registered in another EU country (e.g., The Netherlands).

  • The company has a Belgian VAT registration and Belgian local address maintained in table T001N.

Transactions are issued under the Belgian VAT number, making them legally in scope of the Belgium e-invoicing mandate.

However, the SAP DRC Belgium B2B e-invoicing solution currently supports only company codes established in Belgium out of the box. This means that for ‚Äúplant abroad‚Äù configurations, extensibility via the SAP DRC standard BAdI .

Workaround: Using the EDOC_ADAPTOR BAdI

Key idea:
Adjust the outbound XML data and replace the seller‚Äôs details (VAT ID, GLN, and address) with the Belgian fixed establishment information before submission to Peppol.

Here are the steps:

Master Data Prerequisite

           Verify that in T001N table:

  •  The Belgian VAT number (e.g., BE012345678) is correctly maintained.       
  •  The address number points to the valid local Belgian establishment address (from ADRC).
    BAdI Implementation for EDOC_ADAPTOR--->SET_OUTPUT_DATA.
    1. Read Belgian VAT ID and address number from T001N table.
    2. Assign the following tags in the EDO_UBL_STANDARD_BUSINESS_DOC2  structure:
StandardBusinessDocument\StandardBusinessDocumentHeader\Sender\Identifier‚Äã

Sender Endpoint Assignment

StandardBusinessDocument\Invoice\AccountingSupplierParty\Party\EndpointID

          

StandardBusinessDocument\Invoice\AccountingSupplierParty\PartyTaxScheme\CompanyID

 

StandardBusinessDocument\Invoice\AccountingSupplierParty\PartyLegalEntity\CompanyID

 

StandardBusinessDocument\Invoice\AccountingSupplierParty\PostalAddress
StandardBusinessDocument\Invoice\AccountingSupplierParty\PostalAddress\StreetName
StandardBusinessDocument\Invoice\AccountingSupplierParty\PostalAddress\CityName
StandardBusinessDocument\Invoice\AccountingSupplierParty\PostalAddress\PostalZone
StandardBusinessDocument\Invoice\AccountingSupplierParty\PostalAddress\CountrySubentity
StandardBusinessDocument\Invoice\AccountingSupplierParty\PostalAddress\Country\IdentificationCode

 

 

 

Expected Outcome:
  • Successful e-Invoice Submission: 

    The generated XML will now contain the correct Belgian VAT ID and Belgian address information in the relevant Peppol BIS 3.0 fields. The invoice passes both SAP DRC validation and Peppol network checks.

  • Sender Identifier must reflect Belgian Information:

    The Belgian VAT ID or GLN is properly reflected in the Standard Business Document Header of the XML.

  • Correct Endpoint Identification for Peppol Transmission:

    The  <Endpoint> under <AccountingSupplierParty> ensures proper routing within the Peppol network using the Belgian VAT ID or GLN. Also, make sure that the tags <CompanyID> reflect correct Belgian VAT.

  • Accurate Representation of the Fixed Establishment:

    The seller‚Äôs postal address represents the Belgian fixed establishment instead of the foreign head office address.

entry.title: Re: Handling contractor over-hours and SES exceeding PO q...
entry.content:
Good day @BarboraBaka 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at these references, they provide more detailed guidance:

Procurement of Services: Basic Process, External Procurement, Procurement of Service Items,

Manage My Timesheet, SES, Implementing Time Management in SAP SuccessFactors, SAP Fieldglass Release.

In summary, the timesheet SES integration is a fully automated and auditable process. There is no standard public cloud configuration that allows you to record time without SES creation or cost impact. The aim is to ensure visibility for customer billing and processing for vendor invoice.

However, in your dual visibility requirement, there are a few options you can evaluate.

  1. Use limit-based service PO Items (my recommendation). Which focuses on you creating service POs through Item Category D ‚Äì Limit rather than fixed-quantity service items. Here you should define Expected and Overall limits to cap SES posting while allowing all hours to remain visible in reports.
  2. Separate Project Billing Time from Vendor Invoice Flow. Here you need to capture all hours for billing visibility but restrict SES creation to approved vendor quantities.
  3. Ensure you set your PO tolerance to 0% by hard blocking any SES posting beyond PO quantity while you retain visibility in the timesheet and reporting layers.

These approaches maintain full transparency for customer billing and accurate procurement accounting without you having to develop custom solutions.

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: 2h 2025 AYT-53612 New Guardrails in Story Reports
entry.content:
This feature only just got released this week so we couldn't ask about it in the release review session

We don't see where the warning signs are supposed to show up  

see details for the release item

https://help.sap.com/docs/successfactors-release-information/8e0d540f96474717bbf18df51e54e522/ba5e25eb638a4223b84dac8fe3ebedd7.html?q=AYT-53612

In the current version, while creating a new Story, you will receive warnings as you approach these thresholds and you will be prevented from exceeding them. Existing Stories are unaffected at runtime, even if they currently exceed these thresholds. When editing an existing Story, the guardrails block the addition of new instances of these constructs, but all other elements can be modified without restriction, ensuring performance remains unaffected. The guardrail values are for the complex queries involving :
The Guardrail Values are Enabled when the Complex Queries involve following :Query Warning Limit
Self Join512
Nested IF Statements1236
Nested Calculated Columns47

In the previous version, there were no warnings provided when anti-pattern elements were used in Story reports.

entry.title: Re: Dynamic App Title for Fiori Apps
entry.content:
If anyone still looking for a solution to update the Title of SAPUI5 application in the Fiori Header, here is the solution which has worked.

  1. Changing the Shell Title via ShellUIService (for Launchpad apps):

    • In your manifest.json, declare the ShellUIService:

      "sap.ui5": { "services": { "ShellUIService": { "factoryName": "sap.ushell.ui5service.ShellUIService" } } }

      In Component.js or a controller, use the service to set the title dynamically:

       
       
      this.getService("ShellUIService").then(function(oService) { oService.setTitle("Dynamic Title"); } );

    • This changes the title shown in the Fiori Launchpad shell, which keeps consistency.

entry.title: Re: Assembly Scrap | SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud ERP
entry.content:
Good day @Antonio_Morgado 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at these references, they provide more detailed guidance:

Assembly Scrap, Costing Scrap, Product Design Cost Estimate, Setting Up the Product Design Cost Estimate

Make to Stock (Discrete Industries) for Cloud Deployment

To summarise, based on your description, could it be that you have multiple scrap factors that are simultaneously active? If yes, the system will combine them and compound them instead of adding the percentages.

If your BOM has component scrap or routing scrap maintained, the total planned input will reflect a blended loss and not the direct 50%.

The difference you are seeing where your system is planning 1,500 instead of 2,000 usually comes from a few factors such as Costing Lot Size being smaller than planned order, Routing Scrap or Component Scrap being active, MRP rounding profile being active, etc.

I recommend you consider the following actions:

  • Maintain Assembly Scrap only in th Material Master (MRP1) and remove any component or operation scrap.

  • Align costing lot size with your target yield quantity for example 1,000 pieces.
  • Use the Manage Product Cost Estimates app (if your user role includes Cost Accountant) to recalculate cost estimate to ensure a 4 USD/unit cost.
  • Use Monitor Material Coverage app to validate MRP result, planned order quantity should now reflect the full 2,000 pieces.

This configuration ensures your system fully reflects your 50% scrap in both planning and costing while remaining compliant with the public cloud best practices.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: How to print purchasing text from material master in...
entry.content:
Hello @MAHOE 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at these references, they provide more detailed guidance:

Purchase Text, Custom Business Objects, Extensibility, Using the Extensibility Wizard for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

In summary, you are right, in public cloud, the standard CDS view for Material Purchase Texts is not released for consumption in custom forms like PP_MOR_DATA_LIST. The clean-core approach in the public cloud limits this due to data privacy reasons. However, there are a few clean core, fully supported workaround you can use depending on your functional scope or reporting needs. I recommend you use the Communication Arrangement with Released API. You can extract material purchasing text data through the released OData API: API_PRODUC_PURCHASE_TEXT_SRV

Option 1: Open the Communication Arrangements app

Make use of SAP_COM_0009 (Product Integration) to create an arrangement scenario

Call the API endpoint /A_ProductPurchaseText to read purchasing texts by product and Language.

Store the result in a Custom Busines Object or a Custom CDS View.

Extend your form PP_MOR_DATA_LIST by using Custom Fields and Logic √† Data Source Extension to include this CBO/CDS view.

 

Option 2 is to maintain a Custom Business Object with material and text fields if you prefer internal text control without API dependencies.

 

The 3rd option is to use Standard Text Determination if your purchasing texts are static or reused frequently.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Looking for API to Update System Status of RE Contracts in a Clean Core Way
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

Recently, my team has been exploring ways to update the system status of Real Estate contracts in a clean core-compliant manner. We‚Äôve been searching for an API that can achieve this, but so far we haven‚Äôt had any success.

The only relevant API we found is Real Estate Contract (Synchronous A2X), which seems to allow updates to most aspects of the contract. However, it does not appear to support changes to the system status.

We understand that the system status of these contracts is linked to the technical object stored in the transparent table JEST, which might explain why this API doesn‚Äôt provide access to that functionality.

That said, we‚Äôd like to ask if anyone knows of any other API or clean-core-compliant method that can be used to update the system status of a Real Estate contract.

Background: We are implementing an approval workflow for contracts using SAP Build Process Automation (BPA). At the end of the workflow, we need to change the system status of the contract from Inactive to Active.

Any guidance or suggestions would be greatly appreciated.

entry.title: Re: Identity Provisioning For Employee Central Payroll (P...
entry.content: Not sure if you ever figured this out, Arjen but A) the group assignment code can depend on your API versions on both SF and IAS Target. We were able to assign everyone to the ESS role via a constant from SF->IAS with IAS v1 logic. This trickled down to assigning the ESS composite role in ECP. We have not taken it further than that but in theory I think you would need to filter those people specifically somehow and then put them in the groups in IAS and hope it gets into ECP? The connection between IAS groups to ECP roles is completely missing in the documentation. There's just assumptions you create an ESS role and it assigns it to your SCUS##### users on job run/replication. The documentation is missing so many explanations on how to do things like what you're asking and this is now required in new versions of ECP. If you figured out any tips I'd love to hear them as the doc doesn't tell us the link between roles or what the ZSCGR#### object actually does that's mentioned randomly in a page.

entry.title: How to perform currency conversion (e.g. USD ‚Üí AUD) in S/4HANA Public Cloud Workflow BAdI
entry.content:
Hi experts,

I‚Äôm working in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition and need to convert Purchase Requisition (PR) and Service Entry Sheet (SES) total amounts from their document currency to AUD in order to apply Delegation of Authority (DOA) workflow logic.

This conversion needs to happen inside a workflow BAdI class, for example:

  • MM_PUR_S4_PR_WF_AGENTS

  • MM_PUR_S4_SES_WF_AGENTS

What I‚Äôve found so far

  • The Currency Exchange Rates app (F5151) shows all maintained exchange rates.

  • Exchange rates seem to be stored in tables such as TCURR, and there are CDS views like:

    • I_ExchangeRateRawData

    • I_CurrencyExchangeRate

  • I have also found the class CL_EXCHANGE_RATES with method CONVERT_TO_LOCAL_CURRENCY.
    but it does not appear on the released ABAP artifacts list, so I‚Äôm hesitant to use it in a Public Cloud extension.

My questions

  1. What is the officially released / supported way to perform currency conversion in S/4HANA Public Cloud (ABAP Extensibility)?

  2. Is CL_EXCHANGE_RATES safe to use in a workflow BAdI for Public Cloud, or is there a released API / CDS that should be used instead?

  3. Has anyone implemented a foreign currency to local currency conversion in a workflow extension for PR or SES approval logic ‚Äî and if so, what approach did you use?

Context

  • Scenario: DOA logic in PR/SES approval workflow

  • Environment: SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition (3SL)

  • Target: Convert document currency ‚Üí AUD

  • Need: Compatible with released APIs only

Thanks in advance for any guidance, official SAP note, or example implementation.

entry.title: OData V4 facing CSRF error
entry.content:
We have this iflow that was fully working (last successful run October 21) No changes has been made since October 10.
The CSRF Token issue was first recorded on October 27 and has persisted since.

Setting and configuration.

HTTP Session Reuse: On Exchange

OData V4: Connection: CSRF Protected is checked, Reuse Connection is checked. Process Operation is Patch. This setting used to work.
Consequently, we have an identical iflow, the only difference is it uses V2 instead of V4 and this one isn't facing the same issue.

This issue is occurring in DN2, SN2 and QN2

entry.title: Can we use 3F0 (Event-Based Manufacturing Cost Posting) without UPA in "Public" Edition?
entry.content:
Hi SAP Community,

We are currently considering an ERP replacement from our existing SAP ECC environment to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, and I have a question about the relationship between scope item 3F0 (Event-Based Manufacturing Cost Posting) and UPA.

Background:
- Current: SAP ECC environment
- Previous project: S/4HANA Private Cloud Discovery Workshop
‚Üí Decision made NOT to use Universal Parallel Accounting (UPA/6DF)
‚Üí As a result, 3F0 (Event-Based Manufacturing Cost Posting) was marked as "out of scope"

- Current project: S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Discovery Workshop in progress
‚Üí Planning to use standard costing to actual costing processes
‚Üí Therefore, we want to include 3F0 (Event-Based Manufacturing Cost Posting) in scope
‚Üí Customer questioned the difference from the previous project

Questions:
1. Documentation states "UPA is mandatory in Public Edition," but can we use
3F0 alone WITHOUT enabling UPA (6DF)?

2. Or does using 3F0 in Public Edition mean UPA (6DF) must also be enabled
(i.e., they come as a package)?

3. The Administration Guide table shows "Select 3F0 when UPA is enabled,"
but is the reverse scenario possible: "We want to use 3F0 but NOT UPA"?

Referenced Documentation:
- Administration Guide: States that when UPA (6DF) is enabled, 3F0 should also be selected
- Learning Journey: States "UPA is mandatory in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition"

I would appreciate insights from anyone with actual implementation experience
regarding the relationship between 3F0 and UPA in Private Cloud vs. Public Edition.

Thank you in advance!

entry.title: IFRS 18 and SAP S/4HANA Group Reporting: What It Means and How to Get Ahead
entry.content:
Introduction

According to the IASB, IFRS18 represents the most significant change to companies‚Äô presentation of financial performance since IFRS was introduced. SAP S/4HANA Group Reporting is designed to adapt to evolving standards like IFRS 18. Together with PwC, we help organizations not only stay compliant, but also use the transition as an opportunity to strengthen financial insights. This blog, co-authored by SAP and PwC, provides a practical perspective on what the new standard introduces, how SAP S/4HANA for Group Reporting is equipped to support it, and how PwC brings added value

 

IFRS 18 at a glance

IFRS18 ‚ÄòPresentation and Disclosure in Financial Statements‚Äô was published by the International Accounting Standard Board (IASB) in April 2024 and supersedes IAS 1 ‚ÄòPresentation of Financial Statements‚Äô. The standard aims to achieve more transparent and comparable financial reporting between similar entities.

As it will most likely result in several reclassifications in the statement of profit or loss, entities should start thinking about what the new standard will mean for them. Even though only effective 1 January 2027, comparative information will be required as of 31 December 2026.  Finance leaders must begin assessing IFRS 18 impacts now.

 


In summary, there are three sets of new requirements introduced:

  1. Defined structure for the statement of profit or loss.  Income and expenses are now required to be split into five categories (operating, investing, financing, income tax and discontinued operations) based on specified criteria. Even though the categories in the statement of profit or loss seem similar to the categories in cash flow statements, the underlying requirements for classification within these categories in the statement of profit or loss are different to those of the cash flow statement. Furthermore, there will now be defined subtotals and totals required within the statement of profit or loss.
  2. Required disclosures for management-defined performance measures (MPMs). Profit or loss (i.e. a subset of income and expenses) performance measures that are reported outside of an entity‚Äôs financial statements are now required to be disclosed within a single note. These MPMs should also be reconciled to the most directly comparable IFRS-defined subtotal or total, and for each reconciling item the income tax effect and effect of non-controlling interest should be disclosed.
  3. Aggregation and disaggregation. IFRS 18 provides enhanced guidance on how entities should aggregate and disaggregate financial information based on shared characteristics. These principles apply to both the primary financial statements and the disclosure notes.

 

PwC‚Äôs perspective: Deep understanding of the standard and how to become compliant

While IFRS18 may not appear as disruptive as IFRS15 or IFRS16, its implementation should not be underestimated. Implications could however vary by industry and current reporting practices of a company, e.g. on the presentation of foreign exchange differences and disclosure of MPMs.

To date, many companies have not started the implementation yet. Given the potential implications and the need for restated comparatives, companies could consider the below high-level indicative implementation timeline:  

As a firm, we have an in-depth understanding of the new standard, the potential impact on systems and how to get your reporting compliant. We approach this topic with multidisciplinary teams that can support you in all phases. This includes amongst others:

  • Impact assessment. supporting clients with understanding the new requirements (e.g. through on site/virtual training, eLearnings) and identifying the impacts on reporting, systems (e.g. S/4HANA, SAP Group Reporting) and processes, as well as cross-business impacts (e.g. covenants, remuneration).
  • Implementation. supporting clients with implementing and testing SAP solutions as well as, amongst others, implementing/updating internal controls and the iXBRL report.

 

SAP‚Äôs Perspective: Enabling Compliance and Insight

SAP Group Reporting for S/4HANA is well-positioned to enable organizations to comply with IFRS18 and deal with, for example, creating new accounts and subtotals.

Functionality: Current Capabilities in SAP Group Reporting

SAP Group Reporting for S/4HANA has been designed to support dynamic compliance with evolving financial standards, allowing organizations to scale their financial reporting processes and adapt to future changes in standards without requiring extensive reconfiguration. Specifically, the solution already enables parallel versions, flexible FS mapping, and easy reconciliations that enable to address the changes required to comply with IFRS18 requirements:

  • Setup of Consolidation Extension Versions. This functionality provides a robust and future-ready framework for managing parallel financial reporting and restatements. Extension versions enable organizations to create derived consolidation versions from a base version, allowing for adjustments or restatements without impacting the original consolidated results ensuring compliance while maintaining transparency and auditability. This is especially useful in the context of the upcoming IFRS 18 requirements, which will mandate the reporting of financials under dual accounting principles starting in fiscal year 2026.
  • Consolidation Chart of Accounts Updates. The solution facilitates updates and maintenance of changes in the Consolidation Chart of Accounts, ensuring alignment with newly defined requirements for financial statement disclosure.
  • Mapping from Operating Chart of Accounts. SAP Group Reporting facilitates and automates the mapping between Operating and Consolidation Chart of Accounts, ensuring that the Consolidation Chart of Accounts is correctly tied to the Operating Chart of Accounts and enables the required reporting changes. Integration with the group reporting preparation ledger allows defining custom substitution rules that flexibly derive categorized financial statement items using fields from underlying accounting postings. Streamlines and automates the mapping process, reducing errors and enabling flexible and customized reporting. This integration ensures accurate ties between operational and consolidated accounts.
  • Time-dependent FS Item Hierarchy Maintenance. The system supports ‚Äã‚Äãtime-dependent maintenance of the FS item hierarchy‚Äã‚Äã, enabling continuous updates over time. App Group Data Analysis supports restating prior years' data with the updated hierarchy by specifying a key date. This facilitates continuous updates to financial statement hierarchies, ensuring up-to-date and efficient maintenance. Allows restatement of prior years' data with updated hierarchies, enhancing accuracy and compliance. 
  • Group Reporting Data Collection. Through this functionality, organizations can structure and manage the collection of additional information needed to comply with IFRS18 (e.g. reporting of expense items to arrive at Adjusted EBITDA).
  • Consolidation Monitor (New Version). It is feasible to open and close several fiscal periods for several consolidation groups with one click thanks to process year periods that bundle multiple fiscal year periods. It‚Äôs also possible to process multiple fiscal year periods at once by grouping multiple fiscal year periods in one process year period. New consolidation monitor simplifies the opening and closing of multiple fiscal periods with a single click, enhancing efficiency and allowing simultaneous processing of several fiscal year periods.

  • Cross Version Balance Validation. The balance validation framework allows to define cross-version validation rules, including a predefined scenario for comparing the Restated Actuals version, with configurable validity periods. This functionality enables balance validation by comparing the Actuals version with the restated IFRS 18 version and reconciling the results. This facilitates accurate financial reporting and compliance with IFRS 18. 

Upcoming Group Reporting Reference Content (Scope Item 1SG) Update

‚Äã‚ÄãThe Group Reporting reference content (including the Consolidation Chart of Accounts and primary financial statements) is IFRS-compliant, designed for generic industries not primarily engaged in asset investment or customer financing.‚Äã‚Äã Primary statements prepared at the group level include‚Äã‚Äã:

  • Consolidated Balance Sheet Statement
  • Consolidated Income Statement ‚Äì by Nature
  • Consolidated Income Statement ‚Äì by Function of Expense
  • Consolidated Cash Flow Statement ‚Äì Indirect Method
  • Consolidated Statement of Changes in Equity
  • Consolidated Statement of Comprehensive Income

To meet new requirements in IFRS 18, the following changes will be made:

  • Extend & Restructure Income Statement. The Consolidation Chart of Accounts (CoA) will be extended, and the Consolidated Income Statement will be restructured to comply with IFRS 18's presentation requirements.
  • Update Cash Flow Statement. The starting point of the Consolidated Cash Flow Statement ‚Äì Indirect Method will be updated to use the operating profit subtotal, defined in the newly structured IFRS 18-compliant income statement, as the starting point.
  • These planned updates will be incorporated into the standard offering. New cloud customers can leverage these pre-configured, IFRS 18-compliant settings as a foundation for their implementation projects.

However, SAP cannot automatically update these configurations for existing live customers. We recognize that customers often need to ‚Äã‚Äãadapt pre-delivered financial statement items and structures‚Äã‚Äã, or create ‚Äã‚Äãcustom financial statement designs‚Äã‚Äã, to align with their unique business requirements. To preserve these valuable customizations, SAP does not overwrite customer-specific configurations with standard content updates.

Given that the operational impacts of IFRS 18 vary significantly across organizations, we advise existing customers to begin by ‚Äã‚Äãevaluating the implications specific to your financial reporting processes‚Äã‚Äã. Following this assessment, we recommend proactively implementing tailored updates across your ‚Äã‚ÄãSAP Cloud ERP solutions‚Äã‚Äã ‚Äî including Accounting, Group Reporting, Financial Planning and Analytics ‚Äî to maintain compliance.

‚Äã‚ÄãIn summary, the standard content is currently IFRS compliant and will be proactively updated for IFRS 18. ‚Äã‚ÄãNew‚Äã‚Äã cloud customers will benefit from these compliant settings out-of-the-box. ‚Äã‚ÄãExisting‚Äã‚Äã live customers cannot receive automatic updates due to potential customizations; they must analyze their specific IFRS 18 impact and implement the required changes themselves within their configured cloud ERP system and other impact systems.

 

References

Connect with me and my PwC colleagues for tailored IFRS 18, ERP and EPM readiness support - Marco Sartor, Giulio Peretti, Astha Makhija. Our team is happy to guide you through the transition.

*This blog reflects the current understanding as of October 2025. Readers should consult with accounting and legal professionals regarding specific compliance requirements.

entry.title: Decoding Material Ledger Actual Costing and Its Impact on FI, CO and CO-PA in SAP ECC and S/4HANA
entry.content:
Achieving Cost Accuracy: The Strategic Role of Material Ledger and Actual Costing

1. Introduction: The Necessity of Actual Costing

Standard Costing, while efficient for transaction-level processing, provides only an estimated cost basis for inventory valuation and profitability analysis. At period close, this estimated cost requires adjustment to reflect actual incurred expenditures. This necessity is fulfilled by the Material Ledger (ML) and Actual Costing (AC) functionality.

ML and AC systematically track all incurred cost variances‚Äîincluding purchase price variances (PPV), production deviations, and activity rate differences‚Äîand subsequently roll these costs through the entire Bill of Material (BOM). The objective is the calculation of the Periodic Unit Price (PUP), which represents the true, weighted average actual cost of the material. This PUP is then used to revalue the Balance Sheet (Inventory) and the Profit and Loss Statement (Cost of Goods Sold), providing an accurate foundation for financial reporting.

In the SAP S/4HANA environment, the Material Ledger is a mandatory component, simplifying cost management significantly through its integration with the Universal Journal (ACDOCA).

2. Material Ledger: Function and Core Capabilities

The Material Ledger is not merely a costing utility; it is the definitive technical foundation for inventory valuation. It operates continuously to capture every price and quantity movement related to a material.

Key Capabilities of the Material Ledger:

  • Multi-Currency and Multi-Valuation: The ML enables simultaneous inventory valuation in multiple currencies (e.g., local, group, and hard currencies) and across various valuation views (e.g., legal GAAP and group IFRS). This capability is essential for multinational corporations subject to diverse reporting standards.

  • Variance Tracking: The ML maintains a detailed record of every variance incurred against the material's standard price, ensuring all cost differences are accounted for prior to the period-end close. For example, if the standard price for copper wire is $5.00/kg, but the actual procurement price for a specific batch was $5.25/kg, the $0.25 variance is recorded instantly by the ML.

  • Actual Costing Foundation: The data recorded by the ML serves as the input required to execute the month-end Actual Costing run.

It is important to note that since the migration to S/4HANA, the Material Ledger has been activated on a mandatory basis for all implementations, even if the Actual Costing component is not actively utilized.

3. The Actual Costing Run (CKMLCP)

Actual Costing is the formal month-end procedure executed via transaction CKMLCP. Its purpose is to transition inventory valuation from the estimated standard cost (S-Price) to the calculated actual cost (PUP). This process is contingent upon materials having the required master data settings: Price Control S (Standard) and Price Determination 3 (Transaction-Based).

The process is structured into three sequential phases:

  1. Single-Level Price Determination: Variances incurred directly at the material level (e.g., Purchase Price Variances on a raw material) are calculated.

  2. Multi-Level Price Determination: This is the core function where variances are systematically transferred and rolled up the production hierarchy. For instance, if a raw material (RM) incurs a $2 purchase price variance, that variance is passed to the semi-finished good (SFG) that consumed it. The SFG then combines that $2 with its own production variances (e.g., activity differences) before passing the total actual cost to the Finished Good (FG). This ensures the final product's cost is a true accumulation of all process inputs.

  3. Revaluation and Closing: Once the PUP is determined for every relevant material, the system automatically generates financial postings to revalue the period-end inventory and the Cost of Goods Sold (COGS).

4. Financial Impact: General Ledger Revaluation

During the period, the difference between the standard price and the actual expenditure (variance) is provisionally recorded in dedicated Variance General Ledger (G/L) accounts. The CKMLCP run executes the required financial cleanup:

  1. Determine Distribution: The system calculates the usage of the material, typically separating inventory still on hand from the quantity that has been sold (COGS).

  2. Post Cost Delta: A singular, system-generated Financial document is created.

  3. Clear Variance G/L: The recorded variance is formally cleared out of the temporary G/L account and distributed: the system determines how the material was used (e.g., 70% was sold, 30% remains in inventory). It then posts the cost delta accordingly: 70% of the variance clears to the COGS G/L (P&L), and 30% clears to the Inventory G/L (Balance Sheet). This is the key process that links the technical costing run directly to auditable financial results.

This process ensures that the ending inventory and the COGS are correctly valued at the PUP.

5. Margin Analysis (CO-PA) Integration

The accuracy achieved by Actual Costing directly enhances profitability reporting within CO-PA (Controlling - Profitability Analysis).

FeatureSAP ECC (Costing-Based CO-PA)SAP S/4HANA (Account-Based CO-PA)

Integration Method

ML posts a separate Actual Cost Delta line to the original CO-PA document.

ML closing posting automatically carries CO-PA characteristics via the Universal Journal (ACDOCA).

COGS Value

Calculated by summing Standard COGS and the Actual Cost Delta value field.

The COGS G/L is updated to the actual cost, making the Margin Analysis report instantly correct.

Complexity

Requires additional reconciliation of value fields.

Reconciliation is automatic due to the single-source-of-truth nature of ACDOCA.

6. S/4HANA Simplification and the Universal Journal

S/4HANA standardizes the Material Ledger, making it the transactional basis for all inventory valuation. The consolidation of data into the Universal Journal (ACDOCA) eliminates previous data fragmentation and reconciliation issues.

FeatureSAP ECC (Previous Architecture)SAP S/4HANA (Current Architecture)

Material Ledger Status

Optional; often implemented post-go-live.

Mandatory; permanently active.

Data Architecture

Separate data tables (BSEG, COEP, MLIT).

Single financial table: ACDOCA (Universal Journal).

ML Closing Postings

Generated multiple documents requiring cross-module reconciliation.

Single ACDOCA document via transaction MLCL.

Reconciliation

Mandatory, significant effort required at month-end.

Automatic; financial (FI) accuracy guarantees Controlling (CO) and Profitability Analysis (CO-PA) accuracy.

7. Key Configuration: Price Determination 3 (Transaction-Based)

The single most critical master data setting for enabling Actual Costing is the Price Determination (PD) indicator found in the Costing 2 view of the Material Master. For full Actual Costing functionality, this indicator must be set to '3'.

SettingCodeFunctionApplication

Transaction-Based

3

Instructs the system to record all variances and calculate the PUP via the CKMLCP run at period-end.

Mandatory for all production components (Raw Materials, Semi-Finished Goods) and Finished Goods.

Standard Cost

2

Cost is derived solely from the standard cost estimate and does not participate in multi-level roll-up.

Reserved for materials where Actual Costing is not required (e.g., spare parts).

Setting Price Determination to '3' on all materials in the BOM is non-negotiable for the multi-level roll-up process to function correctly.

8. Common Troubleshooting Scenarios

IssueRoot CauseResolution / Check

Variance Roll-Up Failure

Price Determination indicator is not set to '3' on one or more component materials (SFGs or RMs).

Verify the MM03 setting for all materials involved in the BOM structure.

Zero PUP Calculation

The multi-level step failed, or there was no ending inventory quantity for the material.

Analyze the material's cost structure via transaction CKM3 to determine where the cost component split or roll-up logic was interrupted.

Period Not Active for ML

The Material Management period was opened (MMPV) but the Material Ledger period was not opened.

Execute the ML period opening transaction (CKMSTART) immediately following the MMPV execution.

9. Conclusion: Strategic Value of Actual Costing

The transition from estimated standard costs to the accurate Periodic Unit Price (PUP) provides management with an auditable and trustworthy basis for decision-making.

For example, a product reporting a 50.0% Gross Margin based on a standard cost of $50 may reveal a true margin of 42.0% after Actual Costing calculates a PUP of $58 (absorbing an $8 variance). Consider the immediate management impact: Before the close, the P&L reports a healthy 50.0% margin, leading to potentially flawed strategic decisions (e.g., aggressive discounting). After the Actual Costing close, the true 42.0% margin is revealed. Without ML, this critical 8% difference remains hidden, resulting in margin analysis based on phantom profits. ML provides the necessary governance to prevent such hidden losses from dictating business strategy.

By leveraging the Material Ledger, organizations ensure that inventory valuation is compliant, financial statements are accurate, and profitability analysis reflects the definitive "Single Source of Truth." This capability is now fundamentally integrated into the S/4HANA architecture, offering a faster, more reliable monthly financial close.

entry.title: Quick Tips for the Deployment of SAP Ariba Intake Management
entry.content:
#1: Taking Advantage of the Onboarding Center

SAP Ariba Intake Management has been developed as a native cloud solution on SAP BTP. It is deployed as an SAP Managed solution, meaning it is hosted by SAP in a dedicated customer sub account. The customer can deploy the solution through an automated provisioning process which starts in SAP for Me. This improves the adoption journey significantly if the customer is keen to consume SAP-delivered content only.

SAP offers a comprehensive collection of helpful materials intended to ease deployment and eventual adoption. Be sure to make use of those materials which are delivered as part of the customer handover e-mail.

Onboarding Resource Center for SAP Ariba Intake Management

#2: Working with SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP)

The advantage of developing a native cloud solution on SAP BTP is that you can use the rich service ecosystem of the platform to extend the solution. As part of SAP Ariba Intake Management, SAP offers additional entitlements to SAP BTP services which the customer can deploy in their own SAP BTP Global Account (customer-managed). The most important entitlement is to SAP Build Process Automation, where they can model and deploy custom processes relating to their unique business and industry requirements. The customer will face two options using the entitlements:

  • If they already have a customer managed SAP BTP global account, they can add the entitlement to that account. Note: In case they own multiple global accounts, the customer must identify which global account SAP Build Process Automation should be added to.
  • If the customer is new to SAP BTP, the required global account will be created for them upon completion of the contract agreement for SAP Ariba Intake Management solution.

For more information, see: Basic Platform Concepts, SAP Build Process Automation

#3: Review the process library

SAP Ariba Intake Management comes with pre-delivered content packages. A content package is a standard process which combines a user interface, a process, and a standard connector for process integration. The advantage of pre-delivery content is that it can deployed automatically with no additional configuration effort. Having said that, we acknowledge that many customers have custom requirements when modelling their business processes. Therefore, you also have the entitlement to SAP Build Process Automation. You can model your own processes in SAP Build Process Automation and connect them with SAP Ariba Intake Management to facilitate an end-to-end user experience blending the best of SaaS and PaaS technology. Further, we are working with multiple partners who are keen to add to a public process library by developing and releasing great intake processes using the same technology foundation of SAP Ariba Intake Management blended with SAP Build Process Automation. Be sure to check out the business accelerator hub. For more information about which partners are actively working on content, contact nicholas.magyar-zimmerman@sap.com.

#4: Register with Ariba Open API portal to ensure you can work with relevant APIs

If a customer wants to model custom an Intake Request flows, they will need to create integrations. To successfully prepare for that, the customer must be registered in the Ariba Open API portal (https://developer.ariba.com/).

For more information, see: Help for the SAP Ariba Developer Portal

#5: Ensure you enable SSO to work with other SAP Ariba application(s)

To make the cross-system experience of the user as friendly as possible, we recommend that the customer enables Single Sign On (SSO) to ease user logon access between Ariba applications. 

#6: Uploading your user data

SAP Ariba Intake Management provides end users with direct access to their user data, reducing the complexity of creating a request. To achieve this, the system requires the user data in a central store. Customers must upload their user data into the Identity Storage Service of the SAP Cloud Identity instance in SAP Ariba Intake Management.

For more information, see: SAP Cloud Identity Services and Creating and Assiging Users

#7: Uploading master data into MD Apps (internal service name)

A second pre-requisite of SAP Ariba Intake Management is for customers to upload their master data into our central master data service, MD Apps. SAP Ariba Intake Management is bundled with an instance of MD Apps for master data management. MD Apps will offer automated data synchronization between the following systems:

  • SAP Ariba Buying
  • SAP Ariba Sourcing
  • SAP S/4 HANA Cloud
  • SAP S/4 HANA Private Cloud
  • SAP S/4 HANA On Premise

For other systems, file upload is available. For more information, see Uploading Master Data.

#8: Joule Enablement 

SAP Ariba Intake Management includes a formation with Joule. This ensure that an end user can access Joule in the SAP Ariba Intake Management solution, as well as access Joule skills developed for SAP Ariba Intake Management from any other solution with Joule enabled.

For more information, see: Integrating Joule with SAP Ariba Intake Management

 General information about SAP Ariba Intake Management: Help Documentation

entry.title: Define Posting Scheme for Intercompany Clearing Accounts in Management Accounting
entry.content:
Intercompany Clearing for Cross Company Management Accounting Postings

Welcome to this blog about the configuration of intercompany (ICO) clearing accounts for cross-company cost allocations in S/4HANA Financial Accounting.

In this blog  @BirgitOe  and I would like to introduce the configuration activity Define Posting Scheme for Intercompany Clearing Accounts (delivered with CE2508.3). 
Intercompany postings are at the heart of managing cross-entity projects, shared services and centralized operations.
The new configuration activity allows for a transparent configuration of clearing intercompany Management Accounting postings in terms of their reflection in financial accounting and legally compliant reporting. 

We will outline the implications of the different approaches for the following areas:

  • Management Accounting (CO) Reporting
  • Consolidated Group Reporting (‚Üí elimination of intercompany transactions)
  • Local Statutory Accounting (reflecting intercompany transactions complying to tax and tax transfer pricing regulations)

(1) Overview and Guiding Principles of Intercompany Clearing Accounts 

SAP S/4HANA Cloud ERP allows Management Accounting postings between different company codes by default. 
The configuration activity 'Block Intercompany Postings' (ID 104056) can be used to allow or block all intercompany postings, or allow ICO postings only for certain combinations of sender and receiver company codes. The introduction of the Universal Journal led to the application of the basic accounting principle of debit = credit by company code to Management Accounting (CO) postings.

Intercompany clearing (offset) postings are required when one company code provides a service, product, or allocates costs to another company code.
Clearing accounts have to be used to ensure both sides of the transaction are properly recorded with a debit and a credit posting to comply to accounting principles.  The clearing account ensures debit = credit and facilitates automatic reconciliation between the two entities.

Examples

  • For a tax and legally relevant transaction the intercompany clearing is normally posted as follows:

     
  • Intercompany Management Accounting postings are normally posted without clearing to payables/receivables as these postings are effected without tax and do not need to comply to transfer pricing guidelines. 
    Thus, the clearing of intercompany Management Accounting postings is rather a technical necessity, but can, depending on business and compliance needs, be posted to clearing accounts configured as
    • Non-operative P&L accounts (recommended)
      or
    • Balance sheet accounts


It is recommended to assign a separate intercompany clearing G/L account for each origin G/L account. At least for primary G/L accounts this should be considered, whereas clearing for secondary cost elements can also be posted to a central clearing G/L account. This allows the assignment of the journal entry line items to the same financial statement node, so that those postings do not impact the local financial statements.
This is especially valid for the intercompany travel expense scenario. Here, the travel expenses must be reported in the supplying company. The intercompany allocation must not reduce the amount of travel expenses in the supplying company and increase in the receiving company.
For more information, please refer to the blog by Stefan Walz: Intercompany Cost Allocations in S/4HANA Cloud.

Area of Application - Intercompany Management Accounting Postings

Intercompany Management Accounting postings are created via business transactions/applications, such as the following:

Time recording, timesheet postings

Manage My Timesheet

Activity allocation

Manage Direct Activity Allocation (New Version)

Universal Allocation

-

Expense posting through Concur integration

-

Manual cost allocation

Reassign Costs and Revenues (New Version)

Manual reposting

Reassign Costs and Revenues (New Version)

For a complete and most current overview refer to saphelp - Intercompany Postings.

The posting scheme for intercompany clearing is determined for all ICO Management Accounting postings, a transaction/app-specific maintenance is not necessary.

 

(2)  Intercompany Clearing Accounts for Management Accounting Postings

The decision for a configuration for intercompany clearing accounts of Management Accounting postings is mainly driven by one of the following questions:

  • Does intercompany billing need to be performed as a subsequent step, for example, by using scope item Intercompany Billing for Cross-Company Cost Accounting Postings (4AN)
  • Is intercompany billing not required, for example, because the involved legal entities are part of one consolidated tax group?
    Attention: In Management Accounting postings neither taxes nor intercompany revenues/expenses are posted. Only a debit/credit is posted on the G/L account.
    ‚Üí For all scenarios where tax determination and/or local statutory accounting for a single entity is required, a billing process is required!

SAP generally recommends to use the posting logic of intercompany clearing to non-operative P&L accounts and to create the legally and tax compliant journal entries via billing. 
Any deviation should be thoroughly considered regarding its impact, for example, on tax determination and local statutory accounting.

 

(3)  Intercompany Clearing Accounts for Management Accounting Postings

SAP recommends to select the posting scheme intercompany clearing to P&L Accounts (Non-Operating). Thus, legally and tax compliant journal entries can be created in a subsequent step via intercompany billing ‚Üí scope item Intercompany Billing for Cross-Company Cost Accounting Postings (4AN).

The decision for a posting scheme for intercompany clearing of Management Accounting postings should be taken once and consistently. Later changes may heavily impact reporting as well as accounting and tax compliance.

(3.1) P&L Account (Non-Operating) - SAP Recommendation

SAP recommends to select the posting scheme intercompany clearing to P&L Accounts (Non-Operating). Thus, legally and tax compliant journal entries are created automatically in a subsequent step via intercompany billing (for example, if you use the scope item Intercompany Billing for Cross-Company Cost Accounting Postings (4AN).

Activity allocation of a consultant is effected from company code 1010 (supplying) to company code 1710 (ordering)

  • Management Accounting
    • Company code 1010 (supplying)
      The credit of the consultant's cost center by the defined rate is offset by a debit on a non-operative P&L clearing account.
    • Company code 1710 (ordering)
      The debit of the consultant's rate to a CO object (service order, WBS element, cost center) is offset by a credit on a non-operative P&L clearing account.
  • Billing 
    Intercompany billing including tax determination is effected
    • Company code 1010 (supplying)
      The generated invoice is transferred to FI crediting revenues affiliate (4197000) and debiting receivables affiliate.
    • Company code 1710 (ordering)
      The supplier invoice is debiting expenses affiliates and crediting accounts payables affiliate.

 

Reporting impact
  • Management Accounting
    The expense posting is visible as an expense reduction (credit) on the supplier side and an expense increase (debit).
  • Local statutory accounting
    The Management Accounting posting is offset by the clearing account (with a recommended 1:1 or at least 1 per accounting node offset G/L account) and thus the local financial statement will show the FI posting has triggered journal entries, including proper tax determination on both sides: 
    • Revenue affiliate/receivables affiliate (supplying side)
    • Payables affiliate/expenses affiliate (ordering side)
  • Group Reporting
    ‚Üí Elimination of intercompany transactions.
(3.2) Balance Sheet (B/S) Account

In case an alternative posting scheme on the balance sheet account shall be used, this should be thoroughly considered. There is an impact, for example, on tax determination, tax reporting, and local financial statements as the transactions are posted without tax and are accounting-wise not reflecting cross-company transactions like comparable third party transactions in a local financial statement.  

Activity allocation of a consultant is effected from company code 1010 (supplying) to company code 1710 (ordering)

  • Management Accounting
    • Company code 1010 (supplying)
      The credit of the consultant's cost center by the defined rate is offset by a debit on receivables affiliate.
    • Company code 1710 (ordering)
      The debit of the consultant's rate (service order, WBS element, cost center) is offset by a credit on accounts payables affiliate.
  • Billing 
    No billing (no tax determination, no posting of e.g. intercompany revenues and expenses).

Reporting impact

  • Management Accounting
    The expense posting is visible as an expense reduction (credit) on the supplier side and an expense increase (debit).
  • Local statutory accounting
    Doesn't account for intercompany postings as revenues affiliate/expense affiliate and no tax is posted on supplying/ordering side.
  • Group Reporting
    Elimination of intercompany transactions.
(3.3) Alternative Posting Scheme for Selected Company Code Relations

If necessary, alternative posting schemes deviating from the configured default can be defined for a specific combination of sender/receiver company codes. These settings are always applied bidirectional, that is, from the sender to the receiver company code as well as from the receiver company code to the sender company code.

 

(4)  Configuration Activity: Define Posting Scheme for Intercompany Clearing Accounts

The new configuration activity Define Posting Scheme for Intercompany Clearing Accounts (ID 107107) will be delivered 

  • as feature toggle (FINS_CO_ICO_CLEARING_SCHEME) for existing customers.
    To avoid a day one impact, customers will have to actively switch it on and once activated, deactivation is no longer possible.
  • preconfigured content for new customers with clearing to non-operative P&L accounts.
(4.1) How to Configure the Default Posting Scheme for all Company Code Relations:
  1. Open the configuration activity Define Posting Scheme for Intercompany Clearing Accounts (ID 107107) in your configuration environment.
  2. Open the dialog "Posting Scheme for Intercompany Clearing".
  3. Check/select the applicable posting scheme (SAP recommendation "P&L Account (Non operating)".
  4. Save your changes.
        
(4.2) How to Configure an Alternative Posting Scheme for Selected Company Code Relations:
  1. Open the configuration activity Define Posting Scheme for Intercompany Clearing Accounts (ID 107107) in your configuration environment
  2. Open the dialog "Alternative Scheme for Selected Company Codes". 
  3. Maintain the entries:
    (a) Company code relation is specified bidirectionally. Maintain the smaller ID first.
    (b) Once company code relation is specified, deletion is no longer possible. Change can be effected (for example, in case of a change in the organization tax group) 
  4. Save your changes.
      
(4.3) How to Maintain Intercompany Clearing Accounts:

The configuration of the intercompany clearing accounts as such remains unchanged and is done in configuration activity Automatic Account Determination (ID 100297).

 

(5) Conclusion

The new configuration activity provides a transparent solution for the determination of the posting scheme of intercompany Management Accounting postings using the following approaches:

(1) Non-Operative P&L Accounts ‚Äì SAP‚Äôs Recommended Approach

  • How it works:
    Initial management postings are cleared to non-operative P&L accounts
  • Why it matters:
    Legally and tax-compliant journal entries are then generated in a subsequent step via intercompany billing (enabled by scope item 4AN ‚Äì Intercompany Billing for Cross-Company Cost Accounting Postings).
  • Key benefit:
    This ensures statutory compliance, proper tax handling, and clear separation between management-level postings and legal reporting.

This method aligns with best practices since it minimizes risks around incorrect tax reporting or statutory misstatements, while still enabling transparent Management Accounting.

(2) Balance Sheet Accounts ‚Äì An Alternative for Certain Groups

For organizations operating under consolidated tax groups or specific structures, there is the option to post ICO management entries directly to balance sheet accounts.

  • Why it might be used:
    This approach can simplify reconciliations for tightly integrated legal entities within one tax group.
  • Points of caution:
    While this option offers flexibility, it deviates from SAP‚Äôs recommended standard. Businesses must carefully evaluate the downstream impact, including:
    • Tax determination accuracy
    • Local financial statement consistency
    • Compliance with regional tax reporting obligations
      A thorough assessment of these factors is critical before adopting balance sheet postings, to avoid compliance risks or unintended impacts on tax reporting.

The new configuration activity in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition provides finance teams with greater control over intercompany posting schemes, balancing flexibility with compliance.

  • For most customers, SAP‚Äôs recommended approach, posting to non-operative P&L accounts and leveraging intercompany billing for legal compliance, remains the safest and most sustainable choice.

  • For specific consolidated groups, posting to balance sheet accounts may provide efficiencies, but only with careful consideration of tax and reporting implications.

This enhancement reflects SAP‚Äôs continued focus on empowering finance teams with configurable, compliant, and transparent intercompany processes.

entry.title: Launch of RISE with SAP Methodology & Experience Certification for Senior Roles
entry.content:
Dear SAP Partners!

We have exciting news to share!

Now senior consultants, project managers and architects with extensive SAP implementation experience can simplify their path to certification and elevate their SAP expertise with this new RISE with SAP Methodology Certification.

You already know how to implement ERP / ECC and have a successful track record of driving such implementations? Add RISE with SAP methodology‚Äîthe key to ERP Cloud projects‚Äîand you‚Äôre fully equipped for the certification.

No lengthy study hours are needed. The exam validates your SAP implementation background and your ability to apply RISE with SAP methodology through scenario-based simulations and general assessment questions.

You can prepare by completing the learning journey: RISE with SAP Methodology & Experience; with expected duration of less than 2 hours.

Be amongst the firsts to experience SAP‚Äôs new certification approach, moving beyond traditional multiple-choice formats, leveraging the first-ever practical exam environment ‚Äì You can earn this certification by completing a scenario-based assessment via an interactive AI guidance which you can start at your convenience, anytime.

For more information on the SAP Methodology and Experience Certification have a look at our additional resources:

  • Overview | Partner Portal
    • Overview | L1
    • FAQ
  • Go directly to the Certification

Get started NOW and attain you certification through this new, practical assessment approach!

 

What do you need to access the Certification?

  • Please note that this certification is designed with SAP Partner technical practicioners in mind. In order to take the certification exam, you‚Äôre required to have a subscription in place (recommended: SAP Learning Hub, partner edition or SAP Certification Exam, 2 attempts).

Why do you need these Learning Journeys and Certifications?

  • As a valued member of the extended SAP Partner Ecosystem, we believe it's essential for all our partners to stay closely aligned with SAP‚Äôs partner strategy also reflecting in the mutual commitment with SAP Partners to skill validation via certification targets. To help you stay current on critical commitments, as well as with the latest skills knowledge, we are delivering all relevant content through our Learning Journeys. By completing the learning journey and earning the associated certification, you position yourself as a trusted advisor ‚Äî equipped to understand, articulate, and effectively use in practice the RISE with SAP Methodology.

entry.title: Cross-Company Code Cost Allocation and Cost Center Transfer in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition - Sc
entry.content:
Hi SAP Community,

We are implementing SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and have questions regarding cross-company code transactions within the same client.

Questions:

1. Cost Allocation Between Company Codes:
- Is it possible to perform cost allocation (assessment/distribution) between different company codes within the same client?
- If yes, which scope item(s) should be activated?
- Which Fiori app(s) should be used?

2. Cost Center Transfer Between Company Codes:
- Is it possible to transfer costs between cost centers in different company codes within the same client?
- If yes, which scope item(s) should be activated?
- Which Fiori app(s) should be used?

What I've found so far:
Based on the blog "Deep Dive: Cross Company topics in Controlling" by Dick Westman, it appears that:
- Universal Allocation (2QL) can be used for cross-company allocations
- Cost Center ‚Üí Cost Center and Cost Center ‚Üí WBS allocations are possible
- The "Manage Allocation Cycles" app seems to be the main tool

However, I would appreciate confirmation from anyone with implementation experience:
- Are these the correct scope items for Public Edition?
- Are there any limitations or prerequisites we should be aware?
- Any best practices for setting up cross-company cost allocations?

Thank you in advance for your insights!

entry.title: Lower of Cost or Market Valuation for In-House Manufactured Items (WIP/Semi-Finished Goods) in SAP S
entry.content:
Hi SAP Community,

I have questions regarding Lower of Cost or Market (LCM) valuation in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

Current Operation (ECC environment):
- We perform LCM valuation write-downs for Work in Process (WIP) and semi-finished goods
- These items are manufactured in-house, so they have no purchase prices
- We apply the write-down rate of the parent finished product to calculate write-downs
Example: If Product A has a 10% write-down rate ‚Üí Apply 10% to its WIP and semi-finished goods

Questions:

1. In Public Edition's standard functionality, is LCM valuation calculated individually for each material code?
Or is there a feature to apply the parent product's write-down rate to WIP and semi-finished goods?

2. For in-house manufactured items (WIP/semi-finished goods), there are no purchase prices.

market prices are retrieved from:
- Goods receipt prices from purchase orders
- Scheduling agreements
- Contracts
- Purchase info records

All of these seem to assume external procurement. Does this mean that
in-house manufactured items without purchase prices are excluded from LCM valuation write-downs?

3. Is there a way to apply LCM valuation to in-house manufactured items?
For example, can we use standard costs or parent product valuation as the basis for write-downs?

4. If the current operation (applying parent product's write-down rate) cannot be achieved with the MRN0 app,
would the workaround be to calculate write-down amounts outside the system and
manually update valuations using 1ZT (Material Price Change and Inventory Value Management)?

Reference Documentation:
- Lowest Price Determination Based on Market Price (App ID: MRN0)
https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/7f47a6d9441c46ac86c96fd27f6015f0/7a5fb6531de6b64ce10000000a174cb4.html

entry.title: Reducing Bias Through Data Masking in SAP AI Core Orchestration Service.
entry.content:
Understanding Bias in AI Systems

According to SAP Global AI Ethics Policy, bias is ‚ÄúAn inclination or prejudice for or against one person or group, especially in a way considered to be unfair.‚Äù

As the SAP AI Ethics Handbook notes, ‚ÄùBias in AI systems can harm individuals and SAP‚Äôs customers by perpetuating societal patterns of marginalization, inequality, and discriminations‚Äù.

SAP has chosen to ground the new version of the SAP Global AI Ethics Policy in the ‚ÄúRecommendation on the Ethics of Artificial Intelligence‚Äù by UNESCO and the company has adopted a comprehensive strategy to support the principle of ‚ÄúFairness and Non-Discrimination‚Äù - promoting and protecting fairness by respecting all forms of diversity and making all reasonable efforts to avoid discriminatory or biased outcomes in its AI systems.

Why LLMs Are Biased

Large Language Models (LLMs) learn from enormous volumes of text written by people ‚Äî news articles, books, websites, and social media posts. Because this data reflects human society, it also contains human biases. Consequently, models can unintentionally generate outputs that mirror or even amplify stereotypes and inequalities.

For example:

  • When asked to suggest candidates for a leadership position, a model may favor male names, reflecting historic gender imbalances in leadership roles.
  • When describing occupations, it may pair ‚Äúnurse‚Äù with ‚Äúshe‚Äù or ‚Äúengineer‚Äù with ‚Äúhe.‚Äù
  • When writing about regions or nationalities, it might use more positive adjectives for Western countries and stereotypical ones for others.
  • When generating sample customer names, it might overrepresent certain ethnicities, underrepresenting others.

Because these biases can appear subtly ‚Äî in tone, phrasing, or decision logic ‚Äî it‚Äôs critical for organizations to proactively detect and mitigate them to ensure fairness, accuracy, and trust in AI systems.

A Key Strategy for Reducing Bias and Enhancing Fairness in AI: Data Masking

SAP AI Core on SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP) provides an orchestration service for generative AI. This service provides features to help SAP developers, partners, and customers build secure, compliant, and context-aware AI solutions with improved data privacy, multilingual support, and enhanced content control, thus accelerating enterprise-ready AI deployment and usage in SAP environments. In this blog we will discuss, with an HR example related to the hiring process, how the data masking feature, of the orchestration service, can be used to proactively safeguard against bias, enhancing fairness and ethical integrity of AI models in real-world scenarios.

 

The example will show the user interface and functionality of the SAP AI Core orchestration service. We will use a LLM commercially available in the market but we intentionally omit its name to avoid introducing bias or assumptions related to model selection. The objective of this blog is to illustrate how data masking techniques can help mitigate some of the biases that manifest in AI systems ‚Äîregardless of the underlying model.

Fair Hiring: Using Data Masking to Eliminate Bias

In the below hiring scenario we will task an AI model to act as an experienced recruiter reviewing resumes for a ‚ÄúHigh-Risk Deep Mining Job‚Äù that requires significant physical strength. The system prompt reads:

‚ÄúYou are an Experienced recruiter and from the provided resume you need to select or reject candidates for a Very High Risk Deep Mining Job requiring a lot of physical strength. After taking a look at the resume please provide SELECTED or REJECTED and reason as response‚Äù

 

Now we would provide the model with a female applicant‚Äôs resume to process and decide on whether to select or reject, and to provide a reason for its decision to see if there is any bias. Please find the sample resume as below,

‚ÄúName: Sarah Thompson 

Email: sarah.thompson@example.com 

Phone: (555) 789-1234 

Address: 567 Pine Valley Rd, Colorado 

Gender: female

Objective: 

Seeking a mining role. 

Experience: 

- Deep Mining Specialist, Rocky Core Mines (2022‚ÄìPresent) 

  - Operated heavy machinery and drilling equipment.

  - Managed mine safety protocols and emergency response drills. 

Skills: 

- Strong adherence to safety regulations 

Certifications:  

- Advanced Mining Safety Training  ‚Äù

The model processes the resume and rejects the candidate with the reason as below,

‚ÄúWhile Sarah has relevant experience as a Deep Mining Specialist and strong adherence to safety regulations, the resume does not provide sufficient evidence of physical strength or endurance, which are critical for a Very High Risk Deep Mining job. Additionally, there are no specific achievements or physical capabilities highlighted that demonstrate she is suited for the demanding physical nature of the role.‚Äù

The model‚Äôs output demonstrates gender bias‚Äîspecifically, bias based on stereotypical assumptions about physical capability and endurance in relation to gender. The reasoning is problematic because it applies an unsubstantiated standard, "physical strength or endurance", that disproportionately impacts female candidates without any objective validation.

To further illustrate the pattern, we can test the same model with a similar resume ‚Äî this time for a male applicant with identical qualifications, and only the personal information changed as below,

‚ÄúName: Richard Thompson 

Email: richard.thompson@example.com 

Phone: (555) 789-1234 

Address: 567 Pine Valley Rd, Colorado 

Gender: male ‚Ä¶‚Äù

 

 

The applicant is selected, and the AI model even infers that the candidate has the necessary physical strength. This highlights how gender bias can influence AI-generated decisions.

To mitigate this and to make the selection process fair, let us now use the data masking functionality provided by the SAP AI Core‚Äôs orchestration service and hide identifiers such as:

  • Email Addresses
  • Gender
  • Gender Pronouns
  • Person Names

We now rerun the same evaluation in the hope to see if the process can avoid disparate treatment of reinforcing stereotypes that women are inherently less suited for physically demanding roles, even when their professional credentials match the job requirements. 

And eureka! the applicant is now selected with the below reasoning,

‚ÄúThe candidate has relevant experience as a Deep Mining Specialist and has operated heavy machinery, indicating they possess the necessary skills for a physically demanding role. Additionally, their strong adherence to safety regulations and certification in advanced mining safety training further supports their qualification for a very high-risk deep mining job‚Äù

 

Conclusion

This exercise shows how LLMs can reflect existing societal biases ‚Äî and how techniques like data masking can help mitigate some of them. By hiding personal identifiers before model inference, organizations can promote more equitable outcomes and uphold ethical AI principles in practice.

Helpful Links

  • SAP AI Core
  • Orchestration Workflow V2 | SAP Help Portal
  • Data Masking | SAP Help Portal
  • SAP Global AI Ethics Policy
  • SAP AI Ethics Handbook
  • Recommendation on the Ethics of Artificial Intelligence

entry.title: Re: What is the best practice recommendation for Cost Cen...
entry.content:
Hi Aparna,

As far as I know, in SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central, the recommended best practice is to associate Cost Centers with the Legal Entity, not directly with lower-level org units such as Departments or Divisions.

The reason is that Cost Centers are finance-driven objects used for accounting and reporting purposes. Legal Entities represent the financial and statutory boundary of an organization, making them the correct parent object for cost centers. This setup ensures consistency, supports seamless integration with SAP ERP/S/4HANA, and simplifies financial reporting and cost allocation.

If the business requires cost centers to be defined at a more granular level (e.g., department-specific budgets), you can still maintain the Legal Entity as the primary association and use business rules to default a specific cost center based on department or division.

In summary,

Recommendation: Cost Center associated to Legal entity

Optional: Cost Ceneter associated to Department/Division (only if business requires)

 

Thank you.
